results.title: Typically British: Irish cinema: ourselves alone?
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Century of cinema”.
Typically British. Directed by Mike Dibb and Stephen Frears, produced by Colin MacCabe. Francois Truffaut once observed that the words ‘British’ and ‘cinema’ seemed incompatable. In his celebration of 100 years of British Cinema, Stephen Frears shapes an elegant and witty riposte to this statement. In discussion with other British film-makers, Frears explores the wealth of stylish and familiar images created by the British film industry over the last century. “Irish Cinema: Ourselves alone”. Produced and directed by Donald Taylor Black. Narrated by Gabriel Byrne, this documentary looks at the struggle of Irish people to create an Irish cinema. Carefully intercutting interviews with directors, writers and producers with clips from feature films, location footage and fascinating archive material, Donald Taylor Black compares past and present in order to ask questions about the future of Irish cinema.

results.title: The Century of cinema: Japan and Korea
results.creator_credit: Jang Sun-Woo, Nagisa Oshima, Park Ki-Yong, Eiko Oshima and British Film Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Century of cinema”.
‘Nagisa Oshima’s 100 Years of Japanese Cinema’ is a fascinating personal journey through the history of Japanese film-making which moves from the end of the 19th century through to the mid-90s. A rare chance to see stills and excerpts from classic films made in Japan. Oshima comments on his own films as well as the Japanese film industry and its relationship to the country’s political and social changes. Films by great Japanese directors from Muzoguchi, Ozu, Kurosawa, ‘Beat’ Takeshi Kitano, Manga films and Japanese documentary makers are all discussed. ‘The Cinema On The Road’ is a wonderful documentary which uses the road movie genre as a device to explore the history and current contexts of Korean Cinema. With interesting footage of the Korean landscape and cities, as well as interviews with directors and excerpts and stills from films, this is a fascinating insight into a national cinema which is rarely seen. Both documentaries are in English with interviews and film excerpts in Japanese and Korean with English subtitles.
results.title_for_label: The Century of cinema: Japan and Korea

results.title: The Century of cinema. Volume 1 (UK, Ireland, Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Century of cinema”.
White fellas dreaming. Written and directed by George Miller. Produced by George Miller and Doug Mitchell. 1996. Miller presents an entertaining journey through Australian cinema. Cinema is discussed in relation to the changing nature of society and how Australians have constructed and deconstructed a national cinema through celluloid. A must see for anyone interested in Australian cinema heritage. “Cinema of unease. A personal journey by Sam Neill”. Written and directed by Sam Neill and Judy Rymer. Produced by Paula Jalfon and Grant Campbell. 1995. New Zealand cinema is a recent addition to the realm of national cinema, experiencing a significant growth in the previous two decades. Neill visits the land he migrated to and his experience as a performer and a viewer. “Typically British”. Directed by Mike Dibb and Stephen Frears, produced by Colin MacCabe. Frears explores the notion of the incompatibility of ‘British’ and ‘cinema’ in a personal way to present the outstanding films and film-makers of Britain.

results.title: The century of cinema. Volume 2 (USA)
results.creator_credit: Michael Henry Wilson, Martin Scorsese, Florence Dauman and British Film Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Century of cinema”.
Scorsese’s enthusiasm for his country’s film history is infectious and it permeates this second volume of the Century of Cinema. Divided into three sections, “A Personal Journey with Martin Scorsese through American cinema” doesn’t attempt to be objective or all inclusive. Instead Scorsese leads us through a fascinating tour of American cinema, conjuring interesting connections and unearthing lesser known gems. Includes interviews with Gregory Peck, Clint Eastwood, Billy Wilder, John Ford, King Vidor, Howard Hawks, Francis Coppola, Brian De Palma, Fritz Lang, Andre de Toth, Douglas Sirk, Nicholas Ray, Samuel Fuller, Orson Welles, Elia Kazan, Arthur Penn and John Cassavetes.

results.title: Best of British
results.brief_description: This 8 part series looks at some of the classic cars that have been produced in Great Britain, and have brought years of driving pleasure to fine automobile enthusiasts.

results.title: Best of British: the official red arrows 1995/96 World Tour
results.creator_credit: Tony Wall, Jonathon McNicholas and R.E. W
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Best of British”.
Witness the Royal Air Force Aerobatic Team, the Red Arrows, in their distinctive red British Aerospace Hawk aircraft, achieve the epitome of flying and technical proficiency. This program follows the team to locations in the Middle East, South Africa, Zimbabwe and Australia as they perform precisely choreographed maneuvers in their spectacular aerial displays.

results.title: Best of British: Land Rover
results.creator_credit: Bruce Cox and Synchro Sports Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Best of British”.
This documentary traces the history of the Land Rover through prototypes and production models. The program travels to the locations where Land Rover made its name as a rugged off-road vehicle such as the Andes of South America and the jungles of Belize, and visits the largest Land Rover rally in the world.

results.title: Best of British: Jaguar
results.creator_credit: Bruce Cox and Synchro Sports Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Best of British”.
An early Jaguar advertising slogan summed up the timeless appeal of this great British marque as ‘grace, space and pace’. This documentary explores these legendary qualities by taking a close look at all the significant Jaguar models, from the pre-war coach-built ‘special saloons’ through the SS100 and XK120, the E-type and XJ models, up to Britain’s first ‘supercar’- the XJ220. Interviews with Jaguar drivers such as Stirling Moss and Jack Fairman, and archival footage contribute to a fascinating review of Jaguar’s unique place in British motoring history.

results.title: Best of British: Bentley
results.creator_credit: Bruce Cox and Synchro Sports Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Best of British”.
In the twenties Bentley sports cars built up an enviable reputation for speed and reliability, with wins at Brooklands and record-breaking success at Le Mans. More than 75 years after its conception in 1919 Bentley’s original reputation for quality engineering and ‘luxury with sporting character’ is still intact. Using extensive archival footage, the program documents the early designs of W.O Bentley, the Bower Bentley’s and the Bentley 6. Also featured are interviews with Bentley collectors and a liberally illustrated history of the Bentley’s racing career.

results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Best of British”.
The full story of Aston Martin begins in 1913 and continues through an uninterrupted pedigree of classic cars to the sleek DB7 and awesome V8 Vantage of today. This documentary examines in detail all the significant Aston Martin models from the past eighty years including the Brooklands racers from the 1920’s, the rare 1940 Atom, the ‘David Brown’ sports cars, the V8 models and the latest DB7 ‘supercharged sixes’.
